How many minutes do they need to include for breaks?
However, they need to include time for breaks and lunch. Every hour they want to include a 10-minute break, so 12 total hours x 10 minutes = <<12*10=120>>120 extra minutes for breaks.
How many minutes do they need to include for snack breaks?
They also want to include 3 10-minute snack breaks, 3 x 10 minutes = <<3*10=30>>30 minutes.

context: Jame gets 20 singing lessons.  He gets the first lesson free and after the first 10 paid lessons he only needs to pay for every other lesson.  Each lesson is $5.  His uncle pays for half.
main-q: How much does James pay?
qa-pairs: How much does James get for the first lesson?
The first lesson is free.
How much do the first 10 lessons cost?
The lessons 2 to 11 cost 10*$5=$<<10*5=50>>50.
How many remaining lessons does James have?
He then had 9 remaining lessons where he had to pay for every other one.
How many lessons does James pay for?
So he pays for lessons 13,15,17&19 = 4 lessons.
How much do the remaining lessons cost?
Those lessons cost 4*$5=$<<4*5=20>>20.

context: Karen's students are about to take a standardized test. Karen gets a $500 bonus if their average score is above 75, plus an extra $10 bonus for every additional point the average score increases above 75. So far, Karen has graded 8 tests, and the average is 70.
main-q: Given that each student can have a maximum score of 150, what combined score do the last two tests need to have for Karen to earn a $600 bonus?
qa-pairs: How much does Karen make from the extra $10/point bonus?
First subtract $500 from Karen's goal bonus amount to find how much she makes from the extra $10/point bonus: $600 - $500 = $<<600-500=100>>100.
How many points does Karen make from the extra $10/point bonus?
Then divide the extra bonus by the extra rate: $100 / $10/point = <<100/10=10>>10 points.
How many points does Karen need the last two tests to have for the students' average test score to be 85?
Then add the 10 extra points to the baseline 75 point goal to find the students' average test score: 10 points + 75 points = <<10+75=85>>85 points.
How many tests are there?
Then added the 8 graded tests to the 2 ungraded tests to find the total number of tests: 2 tests + 8 tests = <<2+8=10>>10 tests.
How many points do the students need to earn?
Then multiply the 85 point average by the number of tests to find the total number of points the students need to earn: 85 points/test * 10 tests = 850 points.

context: Hank reads the newspaper every morning, 5 days a week for 30 minutes.  He reads part of a novel every evening, 5 days a week, for 1 hour.  He doubles his reading time on Saturday and Sundays.
main-q: How many minutes does Hank spend reading in 1 week?
qa-pairs: How many minutes does Hank spend reading in the morning?
He reads 30 minutes in the morning 5 days a week for a total of 30*5 = <<30*5=150>>150 minutes.
How many minutes does Hank spend reading in the morning?
He doubles his reading time on the weekends so 30*2 = <<30*2=60>>60 minutes per day.
How many minutes does Hank spend reading in the morning?
He reads 60 minutes on Saturday and Sunday in the mornings for a total of 60+60 = <<60+60=120>>120 minutes.
How many minutes does Hank spend reading in the evening?
He reads 1 hour in the evenings 5 days a week for a total of 1*5 = <<1*5=5>>5 hours.
How many minutes does Hank spend reading in the evening?
He doubles his reading time on the weekends so 1*2 = <<1*2=2>>2 hours per day.

context: Grace baked 4 whole pumpkin pies. She sold 1 whole pumpkin pie and gave 1 whole pumpkin pie to her friend. The remaining whole pumpkin pies were each sliced into 6 pieces. Her family ate 2/3 pieces.
main-q: How many pieces of pumpkin pie were left?
qa-pairs: How many whole pumpkin pies did Grace sell and give?
Grace sold and gave a total of 1 + 1 = <<1+1=2>>2 whole pumpkin pie.
How many whole pumpkin pies were left?
Her family was left with 4 - 2 = <<4-2=2>>2 whole pumpkin pie.
How many pieces were made from the 2 whole pumpkin pies?
There were a total of 2 x 6 = <<2*6=12>>12 pieces made from the 2 whole pumpkin pie.
How many pieces did Grace's family eat?
Her family ate 12 x 2/3 = <<12*2/3=8>>8 pieces.
How many pieces of pumpkin pie were left?
Therefore, 12 - 8 = <<12-8=4>>4 pieces of pumpkin pie were left.

context: Darrel has 76 quarters, 85 dimes, 20 nickels and 150 pennies.  If he drops all of his money into a coin-counting machine, they will convert his change into dollars for a 10% fee.
main-q: How much will he receive after the 10% fee?
qa-pairs: How much are his quarters?
How much are his dimes?
How much are his nickels?
How much are his pennies?
How much is his total change?

context: A man divides 3 hectares of land evenly among his 8 sons.
main-q: If every 750m^2 of this land can be used to make a profit of $500 from every 3 months of commercial farming, how much can each son make if they cultivate their share of the land for one year(1 hectare is equal to 10000 m^2)?
qa-pairs: How many m^2 are in each hectare?
There are 10000m^2 in each hectare, so 3 hectares contains 3*10000 = 30000m^2 of land.
How many m^2 will each son get?
30000m^2 is divided among 8 sons so each son will get 30000/8 = <<30000/8=3750>>3750m^2.
How many portions are in each 3750m^2?
In every 3750m^2, there are 3750/750 = <<3750/750=5>>5 portions of 750m^2 areas of land.
How much can each son make if they cultivate their share of the land for one year?
Each son can make 5*$500 = $<<5*500=2500>>2500 every 3 months from cultivating their share.
How many times can each son make $2500 in a year?
In one year there are 12 months so each son can make $2500 up to 12/3 = <<12/3=4>>4 times in a year.

context: Gina chooses what she and her sister will watch on Netflix three times as often as her sister does.
main-q: If her sister watches a total of 24 shows on Netflix per week, and each show is 50 minutes long, how many minutes of Netflix does Gina get to choose?
qa-pairs: Define a variable?
Let g be the number of shows Gina chooses and s be the number her sister chooses. We know that g = 3s and g + s = 24.
Write an equation?
Substituting the first equation into the second equation, we get 3s + s = 24.
Combine like terms?
Combining like terms, we get 4s = 24.
Divide by 4?
Dividing both sides by 4, we get s = 6.
How many shows does Gina choose?
Substituting this value back into g = 3s, we get g = 3 * 6 = <<3*6=18>>18.

context: Mr. Manuel is a campsite manager who's been tasked with checking the number of tents set up in the recreation area. On a particular day, he counted 100 tents in the northernmost part of the campsite and twice that number on the east side of the grounds. The number of tents at the center of the camp was four times the number of tents in the northernmost part of the campsite.
main-q: If he also counted 200 tents in the southern part of the campsite, what is the total number of tents in the recreation area?
qa-pairs: How many tents were on the east side of the campsite?
On the eastern part of the campsite, Mr Manuel counted 2*100 = <<2*100=200>>200 tents.
How many tents were in the eastern and northern parts of the campgrounds?
The total number of tents in the eastern and the northern part of the campgrounds is 200+100 = <<200+100=300>>300.
How many tents are in the central part of the camp?
There are four times as many tents as the northernmost part in the central part of the campsite, which means there are 4*100 = <<4*100=400>>400 tents in the central part of the camp.
How many tents are in the three parts of the campsite?
The total number of tents in the three parts of the campsite is 400+300 = <<400+300=700>>700.
How many tents are in the whole campsite?
If you add the number of tents Mr. Manuel counted at the southern part of the campsite, you get 700+200 = <<700+200=900>>900 tents on the whole campsite.

context: Mr. Finnegan has 3 tanks with a capacity of 7000 gallons, 5000 gallons, and 3000 gallons, respectively.
main-q: If he fills the first tank up to 3/4 full, the second tank with water up to 4/5 of its capacity, and the third tank up to half of its capacity, how many gallons in total are in the tanks?
qa-pairs: How many gallons are in the first tank?
The capacity of the first tank is 7000 gallons, and if it is filled up to 3/4 full, it carries 3/4*7000 = 5250 gallons.
How many gallons are in the second tank?
When the second tank is filled up to 4/5 of its capacity, it carries 4/5*5000 = <<4/5*5000=4000>>4000 gallons.
How many gallons are in the first two tanks?
The total amount of water in the first two tanks is 5250+4000 = <<5250+4000=9250>>9250 gallons.
How many gallons are in the third tank?
If Mr. Finnegan fills the third tank with water up to half its capacity, the tank fills up with 1/2*3000 = <<1500=1500>>1500 gallons.
How many gallons are in the three tanks?
In total, the three tanks have 9350+1500 = <<9350+1500=10850>>10850 gallons of water.

context: Boris has 24 books and he donates a fourth of his books to the library. Cameron has 30 books and he donates a third of his books to the library.
main-q: After donating their books, how many books in total do Boris and Cameron have together?
qa-pairs: How many books does Boris donate?
Boris donates 24 / 4 = <<24/4=6>>6 books.
How many books does Boris have after donating?
Then Boris has a total of 24 - 6 = <<24-6=18>>18 books.
How many books does Cameron donate?
Cameron donates 30 / 3 = <<30/3=10>>10 books.
How many books does Cameron have after donating?
Then Cameron has a total of 30 - 10 = <<30-10=20>>20 books.
How many books in total do Boris and Cameron have together?
Altogether, Boris and Cameron have 18 + 20 = <<18+20=38>>38 books.

context: It took Dad 5 more than twice as long to vacuum upstairs then to vacuum downstairs. He vacuumed for a total of 38 minutes.
main-q: How many minutes did he vacuum upstairs?
qa-pairs: Define a variable?
Let D = time in minutes to vacuum downstairs.
How long did it take to vacuum upstairs?
Upstairs = 2D + 5 minutes.
Write an equation?
Simplify?
Divide by 3?

context: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey.
main-q: How many candies does Corey have?
qa-pairs: Define a variable?
Let x = the total number of candies Corey has.
How many candies does Tapanga have?
x + 8 = the total number of candies Tapanga has.
Write an equation?
The equation for the total number of candies is x + (x + 8) = 66.
Combine like terms?
Combining like terms, we get 2x + 8 = 66.
Subtract 8?
Subtracting 8 from both sides, we get 2x = 58.

context: Nikola is saving up for a bag of ant food before he can start his ant farm. He wants 400 ants in his farm. Each ant needs 2 ounces of food. Every ounce of ant food costs $.1. Nikola is saving up by raking leaves. He charges $5 to start a job and then he charges by the leaf. Each leaf he rakes costs 1 penny. He finally saved up enough money after he raked 6,000 leaves.
main-q: How many jobs did he complete?
qa-pairs: How many ounces of food will the ants need?
The ants will need 800 ounces of food because 400 x 2 = <<400*2=800>>800.
How much will the ant food cost?
The ant food will cost $80 because 800 x .1 = <<800*.1=80>>80.
How much money did Nikola earn from raking leaves?
He has earned $60 from the leaves he has raked because 6000 leaves * $0.01/leaf = $<<6000*0.01=60>>60.
How much money did Nikola earn from all his jobs?
He earned $20 from all his jobs because 80 - 60 = <<80-60=20>>20.
How many jobs did Nikola complete?
He completed 4 jobs because 20 / 5 = <<20/5=4>>4.

context: It takes 10 minutes to wash a car, 15 minutes to change oil, and 30 minutes to change a set of tires.
main-q: If mike washes 9 cars, changes the oil on 6 cars, and changes two sets of tires how many hours did he work?
qa-pairs: How many minutes did Mike spend washing cars?
He spent 10 minutes *9 cars = <<10*9=90>>90 minutes washing cars.
How many minutes did Mike spend changing oil?
He spent another 15 minutes * 6 cars = <<15*6=90>>90 minutes changing oil.
How many minutes did Mike spend changing tires?
He spent 2 cars * 30 minutes = <<2*30=60>>60 minutes changing tires.
How many minutes did Mike spend working?
He spent 90 minutes + 90 minutes + 60 minutes = <<90+90+60=240>>240 minutes working.
How many hours did Mike spend working?
He spent 240 minutes / 60 minutes = <<240/60=4>>4 hours working.

context: Michael and Thomas are selling their lego collections. They agree to split any money they earn. They sell them based on how many circles are on top. Each circle costs 1 cent. They earned $5 each after selling 100 single pieces, 45 double pieces, 50 triple pieces and a number of quadruple pieces.
main-q: How many quadruple pieces did they sell?
qa-pairs: How much money did they make?
They made $10 because 2 x 5 = <<2*5=10>>10.
How much money did they make off single pieces?
They made $1 off single pieces because 100 x .01 = <<100*.01=1>>1.
How much money did they make off double pieces?
They made $.9 off double pieces because 45 x .02 = <<45*.02=.9>>.9.
How much money did they make off triple pieces?
They made $1.5 off triple pieces because 50 x .03 = <<50*.03=1.5>>1.5.
How much money did they earn off the first three types?
They earned $3.4 off the first three types because 1 + .9 + 1.5 = <<1+.9+1.5=3.4>>3.4.

context: Of 96 oranges, half were ripe.
main-q: If 1/4 of the ripe oranges were eaten and 1/8 of the unripe oranges were eaten, how many were left eaten in total?
qa-pairs: How many ripe oranges were there?
There were 96/2 = <<96/2=48>>48 ripe oranges.
How many ripe oranges were eaten?
48/4 = <<48/4=12>>12 ripe oranges were eaten.
How many unripe oranges were eaten?
48/8 = <<48/8=6>>6 unripe oranges were eaten.
How many oranges were eaten in total?
There were 12+6 = <<12+6=18>>18 oranges eaten in total.
How many oranges were left eaten in total?
There were 96-18 = <<96-18=78>>78 oranges left uneaten.

context: There were 50 people on the city bus. At the first stop, 15 people got off. At the next stop 8 people got off and 2 got on. At the third stop, 4 people got off and 3 people got on.
main-q: How many people are on the bus after the third stop?
qa-pairs: How many people were on the bus at the first stop?
The bus started with 50 people – 15 who got off at the first stop = <<50-15=35>>35 people on the bus.
How many people were on the bus at the second stop?
At the second stop, 35 people on the bus – 8 who got off = <<35-8=27>>27 people.
How many people were on the bus after the second stop?
Then there were 27 people + 2 who got on = <<27+2=29>>29 people on the bus.
How many people are on the bus after the third stop?
At the third stop, 29 people on the bus – 4 who got off = <<29-4=25>>25 people on the bus.
How many people are on the bus after the third stop?
Then there were 25 people on the bus + 3 who got on = <<25+3=28>>28 people on the bus.

context: In a certain school, 2/3 of the male students like to play basketball, but only 1/5 of the female students like to play basketball.
main-q: What percent of the population of the school do not like to play basketball if the ratio of the male to female students is 3:2 and there are 1000 students?
qa-pairs: How many parts are there?
The students are divided into 3 + 2 = <<3+2=5>>5 parts where 3 parts are for males and 2 parts are for females.
How many students are in each part?
Each part represents 1000/5 = <<1000/5=200>>200 students.
How many males are there?
So, there are 3 x 200 = <<3*200=600>>600 males.
How many females are there?
And there are 2 x 200 = <<2*200=400>>400 females.
How many males play basketball?
Hence, 600 x 2/3 = 400 males play basketball.

context: There are 15 cats in a shelter. One-third were adopted, and were replaced with twice the amount that were adopted. Later on, twice as many dogs showed up as there are cats.
main-q: How many total animals are there in the shelter?
qa-pairs: How many cats were adopted?
15/3=<<15/3=5>>5 cats were adopted out of 15.
How many cats were left?
There were 15-5 = <<15-5=10>>10 cats left.
How many more cats were added?
5*2=<<5*2=10>>10 more cats were added.
How many cats are there in the shelter?
This makes 10+10=<<10+10=20>>20 cats in the shelter.
How many dogs came into the shelter?
20*2=<<20*2=40>>40 dogs came into the shelter.

context: At camp Wonka, there are 96 campers.  Two-thirds of the campers are boys, and the remaining one-third are girls.  50% of the boys want to toast marshmallows and 75% of the girls want to toast marshmallows.
main-q: If each camper gets one marshmallow to toast, how many marshmallows do they need?
qa-pairs: How many girls are there?
The girls make up one-third of the campers, so there are 96 /3 = <<96/3=32>>32 girls.
How many boys are there?
The boys make up two-thirds of the campers, so there are 32 + 32 = <<32+32=64>>64 boys.
How many girls want to toast marshmallows?
There are 32 x 75% = <<32*75*.01=24>>24 girls who want to toast marshmallows.
How many boys want to toast marshmallows?
There are 64 x 50% = <<64*50*.01=32>>32 boys who want to toast marshmallows.
How many marshmallows do they need?
They need 24 + 32 = <<24+32=56>>56 marshmallows.

context: A factory decides to stop making cars and start making motorcycles instead. When it made cars, per month, it cost $100 for materials, they could make 4 cars, and they sold each car for $50. Now that they make motorcycles it costs $250 for materials, but they sell 8 of them for $50 each.
main-q: How much more profit do they make per month selling motorcycles instead of cars?
qa-pairs: How much did they sell each month?
They sold $200 worth of cars each month because 4 x 50 = <<4*50=200>>200.
How much did they make each month?
They made $100 a month off cars because 200 - 100 = <<200-100=100>>100.
How much did they sell each month?
They sold $400 worth of motorcycles each month because 8 x 50 = <<8*50=400>>400.
How much do they make each month?
They make $150 a month off motorcycles because 400 - 250 = <<400-250=150>>150.
How much more profit do they make per month selling motorcycles instead of cars?
They make $50 more a month off motorcycles than cars because 150 - 100 = <<150-100=50>>50.

context: Gwen received a $900 bonus at work and decided to invest this money in the stock market.  She spent one-third of her bonus on stock A, one-third on stock B, and the remaining one-third on stock C.   After one year, stock A and stock B had doubled in value, while stock C had lost half of its value.
main-q: At the end of the year, how much were Gwen's stocks worth, in dollars?
qa-pairs: How much did Gwen spend on stock A?
One-third of her bonus was $900/3 = $<<900/3=300>>300.
How much was stock A worth after one year?
After one year, stock A doubled in value and was worth $300*2 = $<<300*2=600>>600.
How much was stock B worth after one year?
After one year, stock B doubled in value and was worth $300*2 = $<<300*2=600>>600.
How much was stock C worth after one year?
After one year, stock C had lost half its value and was worth $300/2 = $<<300/2=150>>150.
How much were Gwen's stocks worth at the end of the year?
Altogether, at the end of the year, Gwen's stocks were worth $600+$600+$150 = $<<600+600+150=1350>>1350.

context: Jim decides to open up a bike shop.  The most common repair he does is fixing bike tires.  He charges $20 for this and it cost him $5 in parts.  In one month Jim does 300 of these repairs.  He also does 2 more complex repairs for $300 each and cost $50 in parts.  He also sells $2000 profit worth of things from his retail shop.
main-q: If rent and other fixed expense for the shop is $4000 a month how much profit did the shop make?
qa-pairs: How much profit did Jim make from each tire repair?
From each tire repair, he made 20-5=$<<20-5=15>>15 profit.
How much profit did Jim make from repairs?
So repairs made him a profit of 15*300=$<<15*300=4500>>4500.
How much profit did Jim make from the two complex repairs?
The two complex repairs each made him 300-50=$<<300-50=250>>250 profit.
How much profit did Jim make from the two complex repairs?
How much profit did Jim make from everything?
So his total profit from everything was 4500+500+2000=$<<4500+500+2000=7000>>7000.

context: Mary went to the store to buy fruit. Apples cost $1, oranges cost $2, and bananas cost $3. For every 5 fruits that customers buy, the store offers a $1 discount. Mary buys 5 apples, 3 oranges, and 2 bananas.
main-q: How much will she pay?
qa-pairs: How much will Mary pay for apples?
For 5 apples, Mary will pay 5*1= <<5*1=5>>5 dollars.
How much will Mary pay for oranges?
For 3 oranges, she will pay 3*2= <<3*2=6>>6 dollars.
How much will Mary pay for bananas?
For 2 bananas, she will pay 2*3 = <<2*3=6>>6 dollars.
How many fruits did Mary buy?
She bought 5+3+2=<<5+3+2=10>>10 fruits.
How much of a discount does Mary get?
For 10 fruits, Mary gets a discount of 10/5 = <<10/5=2>>2 dollars.

context: A school is adding 5 rows of seats to the auditorium. Each row has 8 seats and each seat costs $30. A parent, being a seat manufacturer, offered a 10% discount on each group of 10 seats purchased.
main-q: How much will the school pay for the new seats?
qa-pairs: How much do 10 seats cost?
Ten seats amount to $30 x 10 = $<<30*10=300>>300.
How much is the discount?
So there is $300 x 10/100 = $<<300*10/100=30>>30 discount for each 10 seats purchased.
How much do 10 seats cost?
Thus, the total cost for every 10 seats is $300 - $30 = $<<300-30=270>>270.
How many seats are being added?
The school is going to buy 5 x 8 = <<5*8=40>>40 seats.
How many sets of 10 seats are being bought?
This means that the school is going to buy 40/10 = <<40/10=4>>4 sets of 10 seats.

context: An office has 90 workers. 2/3rds of them are men and the rest are women. The company hires 10 new employees and 100% of them are women.
main-q: What is the total percentage of women in the company now?
qa-pairs: How many women were there before the new hires?
1/3rd of the workers before the new hires were women because 1 - (2/3) = 1/3.
How many women were there before the new hires?
There were 30 women working for the company before the new hires.
How many women are there now?
There are now 40 women working for the company because 30 + 10 = <<30+10=40>>40.
How many people are there now?
There are 100 people working for the company because 90 + 10 = <<90+10=100>>100.
What is the proportion of women working in the company now?
The proportion of women working in the company is .4 because 40 / 100 = <<40/100=.4>>.4.

context: At 30, Anika is 4/3 the age of Maddie.
main-q: What would be their average age in 15 years?
qa-pairs: How old will Anika be in 15 years?
If Anika is 30 now, in 15 years, she'll be 30+15=<<30+15=45>>45 years old.
What is Maddie's age?
At 30, Anika is 4/3 the age of Maddie, meaning Maddie is 4/3*30=<<4/3*30=40>>40 years.
How old will Maddie be in 15 years?
In 15 years, Maddie will be 40+15=<<40+15=55>>55 years old.
What will be their total age in 15 years?
Their total age in 15 years will be 55+45=<<55+45=100>>100.
What will be their average age in 15 years?
Their average age in 15 years will be 100/2=<<100/2=50>>50.
